Tbilisi Central Park Ensemble

Task introduction

The main goal of the project was to create a park ensemble that includes:

  • Pavilion with cafe;
  • Pavilion should cover 200 people
  • Area for young people to spend their time - amphitheatre;
  • Area for children to play. It must be more of creative sculpture installation rather than a conventional playground;

    • Description of the territory

    Central Park, located in Tbilisi, Georgia, used to be a hippodrome. Currently the territory is deserted and unmanaged, people use it as a park and a shortcut/bypass to the next district. The terrain is mostly flat and there is a vast amount of groundwater underneath it.

    Logic behind the project

    The decision to place the ensemble in Central Park was mostly based on two reasons:

  • it can certainly fit 200 people pavilion
  • a verity of possibilities this place can offer

    • The territory is big and chaotic, with no paths or structure. Because I didn’t know what future shape of this park could be, I wanted my ensemble to be as flexible as possible. That way I could place it almost anywhere. Then I decided to position ensemble facilities on both sides of probable path, so they don’t interfere with possible system of routes. My goal was to blend everything humbly into the environment - to create a peaceful presence.

    I wanted to make pavilion and area around it more circular in shape to maintain natural flow of people. A slight difference in elevations helps to make the composition more interesting and engaging. On the lawn in front of pavilion a flower bed, a tree or a sculpture can be placed. The pavilion structure is formed of iron columns and wooden frames - an elegant solution for complicated roof form.

    The playground imitates hexagonal volcanic rocks. It’s simple and yet doesn’t look boring.

    The amphitheater is small and sits 20 people. The hedge around makes it more private and intimate.
